I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  the  proposed 
loan to the Kyrgyz Republic for the Banking Sector and Capital Market Development Program. 
The  report  also  describes  proposed  technical  assistance  (TA)  for  Supporting  Banking  Sector 
and  Capital  Market  Development  in  the  Kyrgyz  Republic,  and  if  the  Board  approves  the 
proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA. 
 

II. 

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT1 

The Kyrgyz economy has overcome the negative effects of the Russian crisis,2 which hit 
2. 
the country in 1998–1999. Annual real gross domestic product (GDP) growth averaged 4.4% in 
2000–03  and  accelerated  to  7.1%  in  2004.  Economic  activity  is  becoming  more  broad-based. 
Growth  outside  the  volatile  gold  and  energy  sector  has  averaged  5%  since  2000.  Living 
standards  have  improved  and  income  inequalities  declined.  The  recovery  has  been  facilitated 
by  strong  economic  performance  of  key  trade  partners  such  as  People’s  Republic  of  China, 
Kazakhstan,  and  Russian  Federation,  which  resulted  in  increasing  demand  for  Kyrgyz  goods 
and  services.  While  high  growth  in  its  main  trade  partner  countries  supported  exports,  strong 
domestic demand and higher oil prices increased imports. Therefore, both imports and exports 
have  been  rising  substantially,  growing  14–24%  annually  since  2001.  The  current  account 
deficit on the country's balance of payments declined from 14.7% of GDP in 1999 to less than 
3%  in  2004.  The  inflow  of  foreign  direct  investment  (FDI)  has  also  increased  from  negligible 
amounts to $175.6 million (7.5% of GDP) in 2004, with $93 million (53% of FDI) invested in the 
processing industry.  
 
3. 
The monetary environment has stabilized since 2001. Inflation was contained at around 
4% on average in 2001–2004, from an average of 21% in 1998–2000. This helped to stabilize 
the exchange rate while fostering a conducive environment for private sector investment. Gross 
domestic  investment  increased  from  18%  of  GDP  in  2001  to  19%  of  GDP  in  2004.  Private 
sector credits increased from Som1.5 billion (2.1% of GDP) in 2001 to Som5.8 million (6.8% of 
GDP) in 2004. With growing confidence in the Kyrgyz economy and its currency, the demand for 
the Kyrgyz currency (som) has increased, as reflected in a rise of the ratio of broad money to 
GDP  from  10%  in  2001  to  18%  in  2004.  This  level  of  monetization,  however,  is  still  very  low, 
even by comparison with other countries in Central Asia. 
 
4. 
The fiscal deficit has been gradually reduced from 12% of GDP in 1999 to around 4% in 
2004. Over the same period, general government tax revenues increased to about 18% of GDP 
and  social  spending  to  14%  of  GDP.  Fiscal  consolidation—together  with  economic  growth, 
favorable exchange rate developments, and a 2001–04 Paris Club external debt restructuring—
has helped stabilize external public debt, which declined from 124% of GDP at end-2000 to an 
estimated 96% at end-2004. However, as the debt burden of the Kyrgyz Republic remains high, 
some  debt  parameters  will  remain  above  the  threshold  for  highly  indebted  poor  countries, 
despite partial debt forgiveness, which the Paris Club creditors agreed to in March 2005. Even

Securities Markets 

 
14. 
Over 1990–2004, 1,596 companies issued corporate stocks and/or bonds in the Kyrgyz 
Republic,  amounting  to  Som31.9  billion  ($4.6  billion).6  However,  most  issues  do  not  represent 
capital raised by enterprises, as they were allocated to individuals as a result of privatization of 
state-owned  enterprises  (SOEs).  Given  that  large  enterprises  were  initially  privatized  to  their 
workforce  and  the  population  overall,  ownership  in  most  joint  stock  companies  (JSCs)  is 
fragmented. There are currently about 1,200 JSCs in the Kyrgyz Republic, of which about 300 
have more than 500 shareholders.  
 
15. 
Shares of about 400 JSCs are traded at the various stock exchanges, although only six 
JSCs are actually listed at a stock exchange.7 All trading at the Stock Exchange Trading System 
(SETS)  and  about  85%  of  trading  at  the  Kyrgyz  Stock  Exchange  (KSE)  is  in  securities  of 
unlisted  companies.  Trading  volume  averaged  only  $22  million  equivalent  in  2000–2003,  but 
increased  to  $59  million  equivalent  in  2004,  mainly  due  to  the  privatization  of  three  SOEs 
through KSE.  
           
16. 
Although  trading  of  corporate  securities  is  required  by  law  to  take  place  through 
exchanges, most securities transactions are negotiated and closed outside the exchanges, and 
are  thereafter  merely  registered  at  the  exchanges.  Market  price  quotations  are  mostly  absent. 
Further,  the  market  is  highly  fragmented,  since  broker-dealers  are  not  allowed  to  operate  on 
different  exchanges  simultaneously.  As  such,  shares  of  the  same  JSC  change  ownership  at 
greatly  diverging  prices  at  different  exchanges,  or  even  at  the  same  exchange.  One  major 
issuer of securities, JSC Renton Group, defaulted in 2003. The incident has further undermined 
public confidence in securities markets and their regulatory oversight. The number of investors 
affected was significant and included the more vulnerable groups of the population. 
 
17.  While  a  market  for  government  securities  exists,  primary  issues  remain  small, 
participation  is  limited  mainly  to  commercial  banks,  and  the  secondary  market  (operated  by 
NBKR)  is  negligible.  Because  budget  deficits  have  been  financed  from  international  official 
funds, there has been little issuance of government debt.

B. 

Issues and Opportunities 

21. 
Since  independence,  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  has  undertaken  significant  reforms  in  the 
financial  sector.  The  Government  has  gradually  shifted  the  financial  sector  toward  market 
orientation  supported  by,  among  others,  the  enactment  of  modern  central  and  commercial 
banking  laws,  encouraging  entry  of  private  banks,  liquidation  and  restructuring  of  problem 
banks, strengthening of banking regulation, and establishing equity markets. However, despite 
progress made, much remains to be done to foster the sustainable development of the sector. 
Central and commercial banking laws have yet to be adequately enforced. Key aspects of both 
banking  and  nonbanking  supervision—including  policies  and  procedures  for  risk  management 
process  and  securities  market  regulation  and  supervision—have  yet  to  be  put  in  place. 
Furthermore, policy distortion continues to undermine development of the financial sector. 
 

1. 

Weak Enforcement of Banking Sector Legislation and Regulations 

22. 
The  remaining  inconsistencies  and  overlaps  in  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework  for 
banking  (paras.  23  and  24)  present  uncertainty  regarding  the  enforcement  authority  of  NBKR, 
which  prevents  it  from  effectively  enforcing  legislation  and  regulation.  As  a  result,  problems  in 
banks  are  frequently  addressed  too  late  and  weak  banks  continue  to  operate.  This  poses 
significant risks to financial sector stability and dampens depositors’ confidence. 
 
23.  With regard to legislation, the Civil  Code, Civil  Procedure Code, and  Labor Code have 
yet  to  fully  acknowledge  that  banking  business  is  governed  by  specialized  banking  legislation 
such as LBBA and the law on bankruptcy of banks. This gives ample opportunity for banks to 
challenge decisions of NBKR, including the decision to remove or suspend bank managers or 
revoke a banking license. In cases where banks appeal regulatory actions, courts often find it 
difficult  to  understand  whether  a  particular  enforcement  action  is  consistent  with  legislation.

24.  With  regard  to  regulation,  NBKR’s  responses  to  violations  of  the  specialized  banking

response to violations. As such, the grounds and procedures for NBKR’s responses to violations 
of laws and regulations often appear arbitrary, making it difficult for NBKR to enforce them. 
 

2. 

Remaining Gaps in Banking Sector Regulations and Supervision 

a. 

Risk Management of Banks 

25. 
A significant risk confronting the financial system is that, while many banks have started 
to  enter  into  new  business  areas  and  credit  is  growing,  most  banks  have  neither  adequate 
understanding nor capacity to manage credit risks associated with lending. On the other hand, 
NBKR has yet to establish regulatory guidelines for banks in the area of managing market risk, 
and country and transfer risk. NBKR also has limited capacity to assess, evaluate, and monitor 
risk management in banks. 

b. 

Cross-Border Banking 

 
NBKR  has  established  contact  with  supervisory  bodies  in  a  number  of  countries. 
26. 
However,  these  contacts  have  yet  to  lead  to  a  structured  program  of  information  sharing  and 
cooperation  between  NBKR  and  home  country  supervisors  of  commercial  banks  that  have 
branches  or  subsidiaries  in  the  Kyrgyz  Republic.  As  such,  NBKR  does  not  have  access  to 
information  that  will  enable  it  to  comprehensively  assess  the  financial  position  of  branches  or 
subsidiaries  of  financial  institutions  outside  NBKR’s  jurisdiction.  Establishing  formal  working 
relationships  with  the  home  country  supervisors  of  foreign  controlled  banks  has  become 
increasingly  important,  given  the  rapidly  increasing  presence  of  foreign  banks  in  the  country, 
particularly those from Kazakhstan and the Russian Federation.

4. 

Fragmented  Institutional  Framework  for  Nonbank  Financial  Institution 
Supervision 

29.  While  several  regulatory  agencies  are  responsible  for  NBFIs,  most  of  them  are 
constrained by lack of budget and skilled staff to effectively regulate and supervise. SCSM, for 
instance, has limited operational autonomy; insufficient financial resources; weak technical and 
professional  capacity;  insufficient  inspection  and  investigation  powers;  and  few  remedial 
measures at its disposal to regulate issuers of securities and market participants. As SCSM was 
transformed  from  a  national  commission  into  a  state  commission  in  2001,  its  authority  and 
funding  is  below  those  of  line  ministries,  and  significantly  lower  than  that  of  NBKR  or  national 
commissions,  which  are  outside  the  Government.13  Further,  while  NBKR  has  authority  to 
establish and enforce suitable accounting and auditing requirements for financial institutions that 
it licenses, the SCSM has no such authority. On the other hand, SCFRA, although in charge of 
accounting  and  auditing  standards  for  JSCs,  has  no  enforcement  authority.  The  MOF 
department  in charge of insurance faces even more serious constraints than SCSM in human 
and financial resources to effectively carry out its supervision responsibilities. These institutional 
weaknesses  are  a  critical  binding  constraint  for  investor  protection  and  sound  sector 
development. The public is increasingly becoming aware of this issue with the recent default of 
a major issuer of securities (Renton Group) and the bankruptcy of the only life insurer (Kamkor). 
 
30. 
There  is  also  a  need  to  improve  coordination  among  the  regulatory  agencies  in  the 
Kyrgyz financial sector. Supervisors have yet to have the authority and adequate procedures in 
place  to  share  nonpublic  information  on  a  reciprocal  basis  and  take  joint  regulatory  action  to 
improve the effectiveness of supervision, particularly with regard to financial groups and private 
placements of securities.

broker  without  exposure  of  the  customer’s  order  to  a  market-wide  bid  or  offer  price.

6. 

Policies Undermining Capital Market Development 

a. 

Taxation Policy 

34. 
The current taxation of income (in the form of interest, dividends, and capital gains) from 
investment  in  corporate  securities  discriminates  against  particular  types  of  investors  and 
investments, leads to market distortions, and prevents investments. 
 
35.  While any interest paid to individuals is tax exempt, interest paid to legal entities such as 
JSCs or limited-liability companies is subject to a 10% withholding tax. However, interest earned 
by  resident  banks  on  government  securities  is  exempt  from  this  withholding  tax.  This  not  only 
favors  banks  over  other  participants  in  the  government  debt  market  but  also  provides  strong 
incentives for banks to invest in government securities rather than in interest-bearing corporate 
bonds,  thus  effectively  favoring  public  sector  investment  and  impeding  resource  mobilization 
through the capital market for productive investment by the private sector.   
 
36. 
Dividends paid to individuals and legal entities are exempt from income tax or any other 
taxation. Given that interest payments to legal entities are subject to withholding tax (para. 37), 
this provides an incentive for legal entities to invest in corporate shares (which bear dividends) 
rather than corporate bonds (which bear interest). Further, since capital gains realized from the 
sale  of  corporate  securities  (both  shares  and  bonds)  are  taxed  as  ordinary  income,  while 
dividends  are  tax  exempt,  JSCs  have  the  incentive  to  disburse  corporate  profits  through 
dividends  rather  than  retain  such  profits  to  finance  investments,  thereby  significantly 
undermining capital formation. 
                                                 
14 Public companies have access to public funds through security issues just as banks have access to public funds

37. 
The Government, which has majority or controlling shareholding in about 120 medium-
sized or large companies, is planning to privatize them. Privatization of SOEs through the stock 
exchange is not explicitly prohibited in the Kyrgyz Republic. In practice, however, privatization 
has mostly taken place outside the stock market15 due to the view that the sale of SOEs outside 
the  stock  exchange  maximizes  privatization  revenues.  However,  the  sale  of  blocks  of  SOE 
shares to the public can increase the transparency of privatization, strengthen governance and 
performance of SOEs, and therefore could maximize the price of the sale of state assets over 
the  medium  and  long  term.  Privatization  through  a  stock  exchange  can  also  foster  capital 
market  development,  as  it  would  significantly  increase  the  supply  of  shares  while  introducing 
market discipline to firms previously owned by the Government.

An  assessment  undertaken  in  2002  by  the  International  Monetary  Fund  (IMF)  and  the 
World Bank against the Basel Core Principles for Effective Banking Supervision2 found that the 
Kyrgyz  Republic  had  a  sound  base  of  prudential  requirements  for  banks,  methods  of  ongoing 
supervision,  and  accounting  standards.  Among  the  25  Basel  Core  Principles,  15  had  been 
either  complied  or  largely  complied  with,  but  those  relating  to  enforcement  of  legislation  and 
regulation, adoption of adequate policies and procedures for a comprehensive risk management 
process, and cross-border banking, have yet to be complied with. 

 
6. 
The  remaining  inconsistencies  and  overlaps  in  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework  for 
the banking sector present uncertainty regarding the enforcement authority of the NBKR, which 
prevents  it  from  effectively  enforcing  legislation  and  regulation  over  sector  participants.  As  a 
result,  problems  in  banks  are  frequently  addressed  too  late  and  weak  banks  continue  to 
operate.  This  poses  significant  risks  to  financial  sector  stability  and  dampens  depositors’ 
confidence, thus impeding development of the banking sector, which could effectively channel 
resources to finance investment and employment creation. 
 
7. 
With  regard  to  legislation,  the  Civil  Code,  Civil  Procedure  Code,  Labor  Code,  and  the 
licensing  law  have  yet  to  fully  acknowledge  that  banking  business  is  governed  by  specialized 
banking  legislation.  This  gives  ample  opportunity  for  banks  to  challenge  NBKR’s  decisions, 
including  removing  or  suspending  bank  managers  or  revoking  a  banking  license.  In  cases 
where  banks  appeal  regulatory  actions,  courts  often  find  it  difficult  to  understand  whether  a 
particular enforcement action is consistent with legislation. Courts also frequently do not rely on 
facts  established  by  NBKR.  Hence,  it  is  frequently  courts—rather  than  NBKR—that  take 
decisions  with  respect  to  banking  supervision.  On  several  occasions,  courts  have  cancelled 
NBKR’s  decisions  to  revoke  licenses,  despite  serious  and  continuous  violations  of  prudential 
norms,  including  capital  requirements.  Further,  the  Administrative  Liability  Code  and  the 
Criminal  Code  establish  upper  limits  of  monetary  fines  for  violation  of  banking  legislation  and 
regulation  that  are  far  too  low  to  be  effective.  To  address  these  legal  weaknesses,  NBKR 
submitted  to  Parliament  amendments  to  a  number  of  laws3  in  2004  to  establish  that  the 
specialized  banking  laws  supersede  other  legislation,  and  that  monetary  fines  for  violation  of 
banking  laws  and  regulations  be  increased.  These  amendments  have  yet  to  be  approved  by 
Parliament. 
 
8.

banking  sector  laws  and  regulations  are  governed  by  two  documents:  the  Regulation  on 
Preventive Measures and Sanctions (1997) and the Regulatory Response Policy (2001). These 
are  inconsistent  with  respect  to  areas  such  as  the  classification  of  problem  banks,  various 
capital  adequacy  benchmarks,  the  definition  of  violations,  and  regulatory  action  required  or 
recommended  in  response  to  violations.  As  such,  the  grounds  and  procedures  for  NBKR’s

9. 
To mitigate systemic risk to the financial system, especially in light of recent rapid credit 
growth,  policies  and  procedures  for  risk  management  process  have  to  be  in  place.  However, 
management  of  risks  in  the  Kyrgyz  banking  system  is  almost  nonexistent.  While  many  banks 
have started to enter into new business, most banks have neither adequate understanding nor 
capacity  to  manage  risks  associated  with  lending  and  other  banking  activities,  which  poses 
significant risk to the financial system. On the other hand, NBKR has yet to establish regulatory 
guidelines for banks in the area of managing credit, market, interest rate, operational, country, 
and  transfer  risks.  NBKR  also  has  limited  capacity  to  assess,  evaluate,  and  monitor  risk 
management in banks. 
 
10. 
Given the rapidly increasing presence of foreign banks in the country, particularly from 
Kazakhstan  and  the  Russian  Federation,  establishing  formal  working  relationships  with  the 
home  country  supervisors  of  foreign  controlled  banks  has  become  increasingly  important. 
However, NBKR does not have access to information that would enable it to comprehensively 
assess the financial position of branches or subsidiaries of financial institutions outside NBKR’s 
jurisdiction.  While  NBKR  has  established  contact  with  supervisory  bodies  in  a  number  of 
countries,  these  contacts  have  yet  to  lead  to  a  structured  program  of  information  sharing  and 
cooperation  between  NBKR  and  home  country  supervisors  of  commercial  banks  that  have 
branches or subsidiaries in the Kyrgyz Republic.  

 
11. 
Despite  the  extensive  unfinished  agenda  for  banking  sector  reform  in  the  Kyrgyz 
Republic, it is important not to lose sight of the progress that has been made in recent years. A 
number of weak banks have left the system, and the recent growth in deposits is evidence that 
efforts to strengthen the regulator framework and effectiveness of supervision are bearing fruit, 
with consumer confidence in banks slowly starting to build. 
 
12.  Much  of  the  measurable  progress  has  been  with  the  legal  framework  for  banking 
supervision.  While  problems  remain—the  legislation  and  regulations  in  force  are  far  from 
perfect—significant strides have been taken, most notably with the introduction of a specialized 
bank insolvency law, revisions to the law on banking, nonjudicial dispute resolution, and new or 
improved regulations on risk management. The introduction of the new law on pledge is a major 
step  forward  in  improving  the  legal  foundation  for  banking  and  commercial  transactions  more 
generally.  
 
13. 
Further  legislative  reforms  are  required  and,  as  in  the  past,  it  will  likely  be  difficult  to 
convince Parliament of the necessity and value of some of the fundamental elements of a sound 
legal framework for the financial sector. Concerns remain about the quality and integrity of the 
judicial system, which will take time to remedy.  
 
14. 
Progress with the actual practice of banking and supervision is more difficult to achieve 
and  measure  than  improvements  to  the  legal  framework.  Within  the  banking  sector,  many 
individual  banks  lack  appropriate  governance,  risk  management  and  internal  policies, 
procedures  and  controls.  For  some,  there  is  little  interest  in  making  the  necessary  investment 
and changes in structure and, for most, the costs and scarcity of skilled bankers are obstacles. 
Within the NBKR, the full benefit of extensive training and technical assistance is not reflected in 
the current capacity of the supervision function due to the high level of staff turnover. There is 
some offsetting gain, however, in the increased managerial capacity in the banking system, as 
most departing NBKR officers are attracted to commercial banks by higher salaries.

Reform Priorities 

 
3. 
 
16. 
Reform  priorities  in  the  banking  sector  include  (i)  enhancing  confidence  in  the  banking 
system by strengthening depositor protection and reducing risks, and (ii) facilitating competition 
and helping improve the range and quality of banking services available to businesses and the 
population. To ensure depositor protection, there is an urgent need to improve the enforcement 
of  banking  sector  legislation  and  regulation  by  further  strengthening  banking  sector  legislation 
and  regulatory  policies  and  procedures.  This  should  be  complemented  by  a  continuation  of 
ongoing judicial reforms, including measures to strengthen the transparency of court decisions 
and  training  specialized  judges.  Given  the  recent  rapid  credit  growth  in  Kyrgyz  banks  and 
initiatives of banks to enter new business areas, there is a need to implement risk management 
in commercial banks and build NBKR’s supervisory capacity in this area. Given the significant 
presence  of  foreign  banks  in  the  country,  NBKR’s  capacity  in  the  area  of  cross-border 
supervision has to be strengthened. A gradual increase in capital requirements and increasing 
transparency for banking services will promote competition and strengthen the banking system.

further  market  development.  The  law  does  not  give  the  regulatory  body  sufficient  authority  to 
effectively supervise the market and enforce securities market laws and regulations. Further, the 
Law  does  not  distinguish  between  private  placements  and  public  issues,  and  the  types  of 
companies which should be allowed to make such offers.8 This is a particular concern in light of 
the large number of public companies in the country. While current requirements are too loose 
for public offers, they are too strict and costly for private offers. Furthermore, the law does not 
require the issuer and the underwriter to conduct proper due diligence. 
 
32. 
Current  securities  market  regulation  does  not  provide  adequate  entry  standards  for 
market  intermediaries.  Stock  exchanges  are  not  required  to  function  as  self-regulatory 
organizations,  establish  and  enforce  listing  standards,  and  monitor  and  enforce  quality 
standards for the execution of customers’ orders. There are no rules governing the conduct of 
market  participants.  In  practice,  nearly  all  transactions  are  arranged  in  the  office  of  a  broker 
without  exposure  of  the  customers’  order  to  a  market-wide  bid  or  offer  price.  Subsequently, 
these  transactions  are  merely  registered  at  an  exchange.  Further,  there  are  no  linkages 
between  the  different  exchanges,  as  brokers  are  prohibited  from  being  an  owner-member  of 
more than one exchange. This is not only anticompetitive, but also undermines the development 
of unified prices for shares of the same company across different exchanges. 

 
33. 
All three current operators of securities markets in the Kyrgyz Republic (KSE, SETS, and 
the  Central  Asian  Stock  Exchange  [CASE])  are  licensed  under  the  current  Securities  Law  as 
“trading  organizations”  even  though  the  Law  also  provides  for  the  licensing  of  “stock 
exchanges.” It would be desirable to distinguish more clearly between these two types of market 
facilities and indicate the types of transactions they may conduct. It would also be desirable to 
limit the listing and trading of securities of listed companies to a market conducted by a licensed 
stock exchange. This would prevent off-market transactions in listed securities being registered 
with  trading  organizations.  The  market  of  a  trading  organization  could  be  limited  to  trading  or 
registration  of  transactions  in  the  securities  of  companies  that  are  not  public  companies  (i.e., 
open JSCs with 500 or more shareholders).

There is room for further development of the corporate bond market. Several measures 
to  promote  corporate  bonds  include  the  following:  (i)  the  law  and  regulation  in  respect  to  the

and other institutional investors should be reviewed and clarified; and (iv) the taxation of interest 
income and capital gains should be rationalized to remove the existing impediment for investing

objective.  To  implement  the  goals  of  the  Comprehensive  Development  Framework,  the  National  Poverty  Reduction 
Strategy,  a  medium-term  operational  plan  (2003–2005),  was  developed  focusing  on  a  three-pronged  approach: 
(i) formation of an effective and transparent state; (ii) building a fair society; and (iii) promoting sustainable economic 
growth through, among others (a) strengthening the financial sector and the regulatory framework, (b) continuing the 
privatization process and improving the private sector environment, and (c) improving corporate governance. 
 
In  view  of  the  country’s  low  income  and  high  poverty  levels,  achieving  sustainable  growth  is  a  fundamental 
requirement for progress in poverty reduction. The public investment led growth of recent years, financed primarily by 
external sources, is no longer sustainable. In light of severe fiscal and external debt constraints confronting the Kyrgyz 
Republic,  the  domestic  financial  sector  must  play  an  increasing  role  in  financing  private  sector  led  growth  in  the 
country.  A  well-developed  financial  sector  can  spur  the  growth  of  a  vibrant  private  sector  that  will  be  critical  in 
maintaining the momentum of growth, broadening the growth base, and benefiting the poor and nonpoor alike. 

 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                            Proposed Target Classification: General intervention 
The  Asian  Development  Bank’s  (ADB’s)  Country  Strategy  and  Program  2005-2006  for  the  Kyrgyz  Republic 
demonstrates that the breakup of the former Soviet Union and the consequent economic decline led to a substantial 
increase in the incidence of poverty. 
 
The latest available data shows that the level of poverty in the Kyrgyz Republic has been significantly reduced after 
peaking  at  an  estimated  55.3%  on  a  per  capita  expenditure  basis  in  1999,  following  the  Russian  financial  crisis. 
Despite  this  progress  due  to  subsequent  economic  recovery,  poverty  remains  a  big  challenge,  with  preliminary 
estimates  showing  38.6%  of  the  population  living  in  absolute  poverty  in  2004.  Around  9.4%  of  Kyrgyz  citizens  were 
living in extreme poverty in 2003. 
 
Rural poverty declined over 1998–2001 at an average rate of 6.3% per year largely due to better performance of the 
agriculture sector. However, rural poverty continues to be significantly higher than urban poverty. About 43.2% of the 
rural population was living in absolute poverty in 2004, while urban poverty is 29.8%.  
 
There  is  general  agreement  on  the  causes  and  determinants  of  poverty  in  the  Kyrgyz  Republic.  The  emergence  of 
high  levels  of  poverty  can  be  traced  to  the  disintegration  of  the  Soviet  Union,  which  caused  severe  reductions  in 
production due to the disruption of geographically spread production chains and the loss of traditional markets. This in 
turn led to rapidly increasing unemployment at a time when the state’s capacity to respond was impaired by the loss of 
federal budgetary support and a sharp shrinkage of the revenue base. The reasons for the continuing high levels of 
poverty are to be found in the challenges associated with reform of state institutions and the restructuring of society 
and  the  economy,  specifically:  (i)  difficulties  in  creating  and  sustaining  opportunities  for  gainful  employment  on  a 
substantial scale; (ii) problems relating to  external and  domestic market  development for Kyrgyz products, reflecting 
the landlocked nature of the country with its trade and transit problems, limited natural resources, and small size of the 
domestic  market;  (iii)  limited  capacity  of  the  state  to  address  essential  needs  in  the  social  sectors  due  to  fiscal 
constraints;  and  (iv)  continuing  corruption  and  inefficiency  in  the  instruments  of  state  governance  that  inhibit  private 
enterprise and legitimate entrepreneurial activity. 
 
The proposed Banking Sector and Capital Market Development Program is an integral component of ADB’s Country 
Strategy  and  Program  2005-2006  for  the  Kyrgyz  Republic  whose  overall  objective  is,  likewise,  to  reduce  poverty  by 
promoting  private  sector  led  economic  growth  and  supporting  selected  areas  of  human  development.  Despite  the 
progress made in implementing financial sector reforms, the contribution of the sector to private sector development 
has been weak, as the banking sector remains fragmented. Capital markets and other parts of the financial sector are 
still  at  a  very  early  stage  of  development.  Confidence  in  financial  institutions  remains  low.  Weaknesses  in  financial 
intermediation and the consequent lack of savings instruments have contributed to the high level of transient poverty 
due  to  high  consumption  volatility.  More  importantly,  the  lack  of  mature  financial  institutions  and  capital  markets
